#Summary1=(human1) General Elizabeth B. Prelogar, representing the Biden administration before the Chief Justice and the Court in a challenge by Nebraska and other states, argues that the HEROES Act authorizes Secretary Cardona to suspend payment obligations for federal student loans since it expressly allows waiver or modification of any Title IV provision in a national emergency, like COVID-19.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The U.S. Solicitor General argues before Chief Justice Roberts that the HEROES Act permits the Education Secretary to waive and modify student loan obligations during the COVID-19 emergency, though Roberts questions whether a $500 billion loan forgiveness program qualifies as a mere "modification."

#Summary3=(gpt4o) In the Supreme Court case Biden v. Nebraska, Solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar argues that the loan forgiveness under the HEROES Act is both a waiver and modification legally authorized during emergencies, emphasizing the Secretary's right to provide relief at scale without express cancellation language, while states contest this interpretation, lacking standing.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The Biden administration is seeking to relax student loan debt relief rules to prevent a surge in defaults after a pandemic-related repayment pause ends, arguing thatCongress authorized the Secretary of Education to waive or modify any provision of the student loan program to provide financial relief to borrowers.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) General Elizabeth B. Prelogar argues on behalf of the Biden administration that the HEROES Act authorizes the Secretary of Education to forgive student loan principal as a form of debt relief during the national emergency of COVID-19, and that the states lack standing to challenge this action.
#Text=We 'll hear argument first this morning in Case 22-506 , Biden versus Nebraska .
#Text=General Prelogar .
#Text=ORAL ARGUMENT OF GEN. ELIZABETH B. PRELOGAR ON BEHALF OF THE PETITIONERS
#Text=Mr. Chief Justice , and may it please the Court : COVID - 19 is the most devastating pandemic in our nation 's history and it has caused enormous disruption and economic distress .
#Text=Over the past three years , millions of Americans have struggled to pay rent , utilities , food , and many have been unable to pay their debts .

#Text=To head off immediate harm for student - loan borrowers , two secrataries across two administrations invoked the HEROES Act to suspend interest and payment obligations for all Americans with federally held loans .
#Text=But , if that forbearance ends without further relief , it 's undisputed that defaults and delinquencies will surge above pre-pandemic levels .

#Text=So Secretary Cardona again invoked the HEROES Act to provide a measure of loan forgiveness to ensure that this unprecedented pandemic does not leave borrowers worse off in relation to their student loans .
#Text=The states ask this Court to deny that vital relief to millions of Americans , but they lack standing to seek that result .

#Text=They principally assert harm to a separate legal person , MOHELA , that could sue in its own name but has chosen not to do so , and the states ' asserted harms to their tax revenues are self - inflicted and indirect .
#Text=The states ' bare disagreement with this policy is not the sort of concrete injury that Article III demands .
#Text=On the merits , the states say the Act does n't authorize the Secretary to ever forgive loan principal .
#Text=But the Secretary 's interpretation of this text is not just a plausible reading ; it 's the best reading .
#Text=Congress expressly authorized the Secretary to waive or modify any Title IV provision in emergencies to provide financial relief to borrowers .

#Text=Loan forgiveness is a paradigmatic form of debt relief , and the Secretary acted within the heartland of his authority and in line with the central purpose of the HEROES Act in providing that relief here .
#Text=To apply the major questions doctrine to override that clear text would deny borrowers critical relief that Congress authorized and the Secretary deemed essential .
#Text=I welcome the Court 's questions .
#Text=General , is this a waiver , or is it a modification ?
#Text=It 's both a waiver and a modification , Justice Thomas .
#Text=This appears at JA 261 .
#Text=That was the decision document that the Secretary signed where he said , I hereby issue waivers and modifications of multiple provisions under Title IV of the student loan program .
#Text=And then that language was repeated in the Federal Register notice that actually implemented that program and constitutes the final agency action that the states are challenging here .
#Text=Well , could you explain then -- in -- in -- in other provisions , there is express language as to cancellation , and , of course , there is n't here .
#Text=So would you take a minute to explain how a waiver or modification amounts to a waiver -- to a cancellation ?
#Text=Of course .

#Text=So the Secretary identified various provisions in Title IV that govern the terms and conditions of student loans and also govern discharge and cancellation in other circumstances , as your question suggested .

#Text=And I think the straightforward way to think about how the verbs map onto the Secretary 's action is that he waived elements of those provisions that contain eligibility requirements for discharge and cancellation that are inapplicable under this program and then modified the provisions to contain the limitations that he had announced as part and parcel of announcing this loan forgiveness .

#Text=Now you had suggested that there 's no express statement in the HEROES Act to discharge loan principal , and that 's true , but the relevant and operative language here is the provision that says the Secretary is empowered to waive or modify any Title IV provision , and so the HEROES Act is n't enumerating any of the various forms of relief that have long been authorized and implemented under this statute .

#Text=I do n't think anything can be read into the fact that there 's no express reference to particular forms of relief because Congress was trying to broadly cover the field and ensure that the Secretary had the tools to respond to the national emergency with whatever relief might be necessitated .
#Text=But , in an opinion we had a few years ago by Justice Scalia , he talked about what the word " modify " means , and he said modified in our view connotes moderate change .

#Text=He said it might be good English to say that the French Revolution modified the status of the French nobility , but only because there 's a figure of speech called understatement and a literary device known as sarcasm .
#Text=We 're talking about half a trillion dollars and 43 million Americans .
#Text=How does that fit under the normal understanding of " modifying " ?

#Text=So , of course , I recognize that in MCI , Justice Scalia 's opinion adopted a narrower understanding of that term , but I do n't read that opinion to set forth a universal meaning of " modify , " no matter the statutory context .
#Text=And , here , of course , we have a broader phrase , " waive or modify . "
#Text=It 's undisputed and the states are n't contesting that the ordinary meaning of " waive " means to eliminate an obligation in its entirety .
#Text=And I think , if you look at that phrase in the context of the statute , that means that " modify " has to mean making a change up to the point of wholesale elimination .
#Text=It would be really strange for Congress to say you can eliminate obligations altogether or tweak them just the littlest bit , but you ca n't do anything in between .
#Text=Well , but it 's " waive " particular regulatory or statutory provisions .
#Text=That 's right .
#Text=That to me suggests a much more focused use of the word .
#Text=Well , it 's " waive or modify " paired with the authority to do that with respect to any Title IV provision .
#Text=So I think that that is the –
#Text=It does n't say waive -- modify or waive loan balances .
